results.title: Sacred groves [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Celts”.
The third in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000, this time with a focus on the Celts of Great Britain, Ireland and Wales and the ancient pagan religion of Druidism and its translation into the present day. The program discusses the fertility rights, rituals and burial rights that formed a large part of Celtic folk tradition and their mythology about the world after death with a focus on archaeological findings of riches and human remains in burial mounds as well as in peat bogs throughout Wales. The foundation of our present day Halloween in the ancient Celtic Feast of the Dead, where the earthly and supernatural world were said to intersect with nightmarish possibilities, is given as a striking example of a softened contemporary translation of ancient folklore. To this end a study is also made of the present day translation of Celtic religion, seen as a fairly removed version of the powerful Druidism of ancient times where, firmly routed in an engagement with nature, Druids were trained for twenty years to take their position in the highest priestly caste of the three orders and where great importance was placed on poetic Bards, sacrifice and no less than 200 gods and goddesses. The Druids’ fearful appearance to the Romans is also detailed, along with the stories of Druid rebellion against Roman invasion, let down in the end by lack of organisation against the most disciplined army of the world at that time and resulting in many elements of Druidism being banned or encapsulated in Catholicism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

results.title: Heroes in defeat [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Celts”.
The second in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. A study of rock art and archaeological findings of jewellery and various artefacts opens the program with a discussion of their symbolism that has remained relatively unknown for centuries save for their significance to key events and rituals inherent in the Celtic civilisation and their stylistic originality now known as ‘Celtic Art’. The program then traces the breakdown of Celtic society in the fifth century BC as a mass movement South of the Celtic population on the continent led to clashes with Rome and Delphi and a distribution of Celtic peoples to unexpected corners of the globe with a discussion of the great many theories that seek to explain this. The Celts in Britain are then examined in detail, with explanation of the ancient history associated with their presence there and the powerful farming, artistic and warrior traditions of their society. In tandem, the growth of the threat of the new Roman Empire to the Celts and the invasion of Celt’s new developing urban centres throughout the continent is detailed where despite the emergence of revolutionary leaders the strength of the Celts was no match for the discipline and well informed warfare techniques of the Roman soldiers. As the Roman Empire expanded its outreach Celtic Britain also came under attack but with a view to the next instalment in the series, it is said that they weren’t quite as successful in this endeavour as many believe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

results.title: In the beginning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Celts”.
The first in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This episode asks the questions as to what defines the Celts, both in myth and in genetics. The program opens with discussion of the origins of the Celts in central Europe, far from where they later settled, and examines their distinctive culture and rituals as evidenced in cave drawings, writings of other cultures and archaelogical findings. The tradition of sunworshipping, the movement westward as the weather changed and the gradual move to the iron age is discussed along with the changes in power structures, produce and cultural influences in the Celtic world as trade and thus riches increased. These elements are discussed with reference to archaelogical study while acknowledging the indefinate nature of the history of the Celtic people. The questions that arise as to how they got to Ireland, the area where the contemporary true Celts remain, are investigated with reference to conflicting theories about coastal migration patterns of the time or the ambiguous archaeological evidence which is featured in the area in order to illustrate some possibilities given the difficulty of tracing Celtic history. A study is also recorded in this program of the population in present day Celtic areas and their heritage through a genetic heritage testing project with local school children and a discussion of their family heritage. While the study is seen to shed an interesting light on tracing Celtic history through genetic means it also confirms and engages with the discussion in the rest of the program of the enigma that the Celts remain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

results.title: Japan: Tokyo to Taiwan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Ian Wright conducts this Lonely planet tour of Japan, experiencing the bullet train at 160 miles per hour, having his fortune read at a Buddhist shrine, visiting the peace museum in Nagasaki, and soaking up the fantastic environment at the Aso Fire Festival.

results.title: Cuba and Haiti
results.creator_credit: Jenny Dames, Dawn Beresford and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Cuba is the largest and least commercialised country in the Caribbean. Political factors too have kept tourists away since Castro’s revolution in the fifties. Beginning his journey in the famous Cuban capital of Havana, Ian Wright travels across Cuba, skydiving onto a Havana beach, visiting a Cuban cigar factory, swimming with dolphins, visiting the Che Guevara University and watching a voodoo ceremony in Haiti. His journey ends in Haiti, the oldest black republic in the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jenny Dames, Dawn Beresford and Pilot Films

results.title: Experience Indonesia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Independent traveller Mark Crowdy, avoiding the more popular tourist resorts, travels to the lesser known eastern islands of Flores, Komodo, Amban and Banda. His ultimate aim was “to find people and places who hadn’t been jaded by tourism.” The Lonely Planet travel series opens up new possibilities in travelling for the intrepid explorer, while armchair travellers can sit back in comfort and enjoy rare and beautiful locations.

results.title: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 2.
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, Robert Francis, Anthony Buckley, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Episode 3: Arising from the ashes. 1949-1970. The post-war film world was dominated by Hollywood giants but local heroes achieved huge success in “Smiley” and “Jedda” with stars like Chips Rafferty and Bud Tingwell. This episode explores the influences which encouraged success in the Australian film industry and overviews Australian life during the Menzies era and ‘60’s - the point where the industry gained a financial footing for the first time in decades. Episode 4: Beyond our wildest dreams. 1971-1995. The era when our cinema was reborn with the classics “Picnic at hanging rock”, The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith”, “Mad Max”, “Breaker Morant” and “Gallipoli. This renaissance fostered the talents of Mel Gibson, Judy Davis and the directors Peter Weir, Gillian Armstrong, George Miller and Bruce Beresford. Australia’s image internationally consolidated with “Crocodile Dundee”, Strictly Ballroom”, “The Adventures of Priscilla Queen of the Desert and “Muriel’s Wedding”. Within 25 years the film industry had moved from near extinction to a point beyond our wildest dreams. Narrated by Bryan Brown.
results.title_for_label: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 2.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Crombie, Robert Francis, Anthony Buckley, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.description: Episode 3: Arising from the ashes. 1949-1970. The post-war film world was dominated by Hollywood giants but local heroes achieved huge success in “Smiley” and “Jedda” with stars like Chips Rafferty and Bud Tingwell. This episode explores the influences which encouraged success in the Australian film industry and overviews Australian life during the Menzies era and ‘60’s - the point where the industry gained a financial footing for the first time in decades. Episode 4: Beyond our wildest dreams. 1971-1995. The era when our cinema was reborn with the classics “Picnic at hanging rock”, The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith”, “Mad Max”, “Breaker Morant” and “Gallipoli. This renaissance fostered the talents of Mel Gibson, Judy Davis and the directors Peter Weir, Gillian Armstrong, George Miller and Bruce Beresford. Australia’s image internationally consolidated with “Crocodile Dundee”, Strictly Ballroom”, “The Adventures of Priscilla Queen of the Desert and “Muriel’s Wedding”. Within 25 years the film industry had moved from near extinction to a point beyond our wildest dreams. Narrated by Bryan Brown.

results.title: Argentina
results.creator_credit: Colin Napthine, Deborah Hinnigan and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Argentina is a land of many contrasts, a land where the magnificent desolation of Patagonia and the Andes contrast dramatically with the urban frenzy of Buenos Aires, one of the world’s largest and most cosmopolitan cities. In this instalment of ‘The Lonely planet’ series, traveller Justine Shapiro visits Iguazu Falls, travels on one of the most spectacular railway journeys in Latin America, spends a day with gauchos, learns to tango, and visits the San Moreno glacier at the tip of Latin America.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Napthine, Deborah Hinnigan and Pilot Films

results.title: The Cat returns = Neko no ongaeshi
results.creator_credit: Hiroyuki Morita, Nozomu Takahashi, Toshio Suzuki and Studio Ghibli
results.brief_description: Animated fantasy adventure about a young high school girl, Haru, who finds herself being rewarded for a good deed carried out as a child. She simply feeds a hungry kitten but when this unique kitten grows, it is decided in the cat kingdom that Haru is special and should be given gifts. Daughter of a single mother, the young girl has the usual teenage angst and wants to impress the handsome boy in her class. Her usual routine is forgotten however as she is transported to the Kingdom of Cats. Haru also unwittingly finds herself engaged to the Prince of Cats! A coming-of-age film with a difference as this is a magical and fantastic adventure suitable for family viewing. From the creators of award winning “Spirited Away” [318123] the moving classical soundtrack adds to the enchanting nature of the story.

results.title: The Cat came back
results.creator_credit: Cordell Barker, Richard Condie and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This hilarious animated short is based on the century-old folk song of the same name. Old Mr. Johnson makes increasingly manic attempts to rid himself of a little yellow cat that just won’t stay away.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cordell Barker, Richard Condie and National Film Board of Canada
